channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: Quake Death Toll Passes 15,000 in Turkey and Syria as Desperation Builds
item.description: The death toll from the devastating earthquake in Turkey and Syria rose as rescuers faced shortages of trucks, fuel and time. President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey visited the area near the epicenter.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Emin Ozmen for The New York Times

item.title: In Rural Ukraine, a Mobile Clinic Provides Medicine and Hope
item.description: A mobile clinic is trying to restore medical services to villages once occupied by Russian forces as fighting rages nearby. “They’ll never beat our people,” a specialist with the team said.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz and Lynsey Addario
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times

item.title: Syrian Refugees Who Died in Turkey Earthquake Are Returned Home
item.description: Millions fled the war in Syria for the safety of neighboring Turkey. “We want them to be buried among their family,” said a man waiting for the body of a young relative coming from Turkey.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim and Muhammad Haj Kadour
item.media:description: A man on the Syrian side of the Bab al-Hawa border crossing carries the body of a relative killed in Turkey.

item.title: What’s a Japanese Mobster to Do in Retirement? Join a Softball Team.
item.description: The members of the Ryuyukai have done nearly 100 years of hard time. Now they’re just looking to stay out of trouble.
item.dc:creator: Ben Dooley, Hisako Ueno and Shiho Fukada
item.media:credit: Shiho Fukada for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yuji Ryuzaki, foreground, with other members of the Ryuyukai softball team at a game in suburban Tokyo last year.

item.title: Greece Moves to Block Far-Right Party as Election Nears
item.description: A new law targets a party founded by an imprisoned former official of the neo-Nazi group Golden Dawn. But critics say its reach could be wider.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis
item.media:description: Ilias Kasidiaris, the founder of National Party — Greeks, during a protest against Turkey in Athens, Greece, in 2018.

item.title: Élisabeth Borne, France’s Prime Minister, on Her Harrowing Story
item.description: The daughter of an Auschwitz survivor, Élisabeth Borne has avoided bringing her past into politics, even when it might be appropriate.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter and Aurelien Breeden
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: France’s prime minister, Élisabeth Borne, in December in her office in Paris.

item.title: ‘Troubling’ Race Disparity Is Found in U.K. Prosecution Decisions
item.description: Black and biracial people in England and Wales are significantly more likely to be prosecuted than white people who have been arrested on comparable charges, according to a major study.
item.dc:creator: Jane Bradley
item.media:credit: Aaron Chown/PA Images, via Getty Images
item.media:description: The Royal Courts of Justice in London. The figures support what civil rights groups and ethnic minority residents have said for years: that Black people face disproportionately harsh treatment.

item.title: Britain Pledges to Train Ukraine’s Pilots, Signaling That Warplanes Could Come Next
item.description: The training is a “first step,” Prime Minister Rishi Sunak told President Volodymyr Zelensky, who then went to Paris to meet with the French and German leaders.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine in Kyiv, the country’s capital, last week.

item.title: Lost Letters by Mary, Queen of Scots, Uncovered by Code Breakers
item.description: The messages, written while she was imprisoned by her cousin Queen Elizabeth I, were mistakenly listed as Italian texts in France’s national library.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward
item.media:description: Mary, Queen of Scots, fled Scotland after being forced to abdicate in 1567 but then spent 19 years as a prisoner in England.

item.title: China Sends Spy Balloons Over Military Sites Worldwide, U.S. Officials Say
item.description: The balloons have some advantages over the satellites that orbit the earth in regular patterns. They fly closer to earth and can evade radar.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes, Edward Wong, Helene Cooper and Chris Buckley
item.media:description: A photograph provided by the U.S. Navy showing sailors recovering the Chinese balloon in the waters off South Carolina on Sunday.

item.title: After the Quake: Photos and Videos From Turkey and Syria
item.description: The deadly earthquake was felt in at least four countries, with most of the casualties and the heaviest damage reported in Turkey and Syria.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rescue workers removing the rubble from a collapsed house in Iskenderun, Turkey.

item.title: Turks and Syrians Abroad Rally to Help Their Homelands After Earthquake
item.description: An outpouring of donations is flowing from around the world, as communities struggle to ease feelings of helplessness — and the agony of waiting for loved ones who have not called.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon, Natasha Frost and Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: Members of the Turkish community in Berlin collected bags and boxes with warm clothes and other goods on Tuesday to support victims of the deadly earthquake in Turkey.

item.title: 2 Children Killed After Bus Driver Crashes Into Day Care Near Montreal
item.description: The police in Laval, Quebec, said that six other children were injured and that the driver had been charged with first-degree murder.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson, Vjosa Isai and Amanda Holpuch
item.media:description: Two children were killed and six others were injured when a driver crashed a bus into a day care center in Laval, Quebec, outside Montreal.

item.title: What China’s Military Balloons Show About Its Spying Ambitions
item.description: Chinese military scientists have been looking for ways to make them more durable, harder to detect and even to serve as platforms that fire advanced weapons.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley and Amy Chang Chien
item.media:description: The Chinese spy balloon that floated over the United States seemed a new phenomenon. But China has long tested and used balloons as surveillance craft.

item.title: Life on the Beat for Ukraine’s Cops: The Drunk, the Disorderly and Drones
item.description: In cities dealing with bombardment and blackouts, the Patrol Police have taken a lead in trying to retain a sense of security for a traumatized public.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Officer Svitlana Lukianenkova, 30, and her Patrol Police colleague Officer Stanislav Skrypnyk, 28, at work in Kyiv, Ukraine, in December.

item.title: Freed Guantánamo Prisoner Has Big Dreams for a New Life in Belize
item.description: Majid Khan, a “high-value detainee” at Guantánamo Bay, was released last week after two decades of social isolation.
item.dc:creator: Carol Rosenberg
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times

item.title: Can China Reverse Its Population Decline? Just Ask Sweden.
item.description: Wealthy countries have been trying to boost their birthrates for decades. The results have been pretty similar.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Jacobs and Francesca Paris

item.title: U.S. Aims to Curb Investment in China Amid Security Concerns
item.description: The Biden administration is preparing new rules that would restrict U.S. dollars from flowing to China.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson and Lauren Hirsch
item.media:credit: Zhong Min/Feature China, via Future Publishing, via Getty Images
item.media:description: The administration’s measures would prohibit outright investments in sensitive areas like quantum computing, advanced semiconductors, and artificial intelligence capabilities used by the military.

item.title: Kizzmekia Corbett Unlocked the Science of the Covid Vaccine
item.description: Kizzmekia Corbett helped lead a team of scientists contributing to one of the most stunning achievements in the history of immunizations: a highly effective, easily manufactured vaccine against Covid-19.
item.dc:creator: Debra Kamin
item.media:credit: Kayana Szymczak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kizzmekia Corbett was at the vanguard of the race for a vaccine against Covid-19. Above, she is in her office at the Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health in Boston.

item.title: North Korea Urges ‘Preparedness for War’ and Displays New Missile
item.description: Analysts said the new weapon was probably a solid-fuel ICBM, which the North’s leader, Kim Jong-un, has wanted to add to his country’s growing nuclear arsenal.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Korean Central News Agency, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A photograph provided by North Korean state media showed an intercontinental ballistic missile during a military parade celebrating the 75th anniversary of the North Korean army in Pyongyang on Wednesday.

item.title: He Set Off Across Australia on a Toy Scooter. Then Australia Got on Board.
item.description: An improbable journey by a Japanese visitor chronicling his adventures on social media has captured the country’s imagination.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost and Hikari Hida
item.media:description: Ryokei Mifune, who goes by Uni, during his journey across Australia.

item.title: Rebuilding Quake-Stricken Cities in Turkey and Syria May Take Decade
item.description: While intact buildings might look fine, their structural integrity might have been damaged. Some of these buildings will have to be torn down. This process alone could take years.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Destroyed buildings in Hatay, Turkey, on Wednesday.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: The latest from rescue efforts in Turkey and Syria.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Emily Garthwaite for The New York Times
item.media:description: Two neighboring families sharing a tent in Antakya, Turkey.

item.title: An Underground Hospital in Syria Fills With Quake Victims
item.description: A subterranean hospital known as the Cave and long the destination for war wounded is now filled with casualties of the earthquake — both alive and dead.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht

item.title: Turkey-Syria Earthquake: Millions Await Aid While Suffering Cold and Grief
item.description: With thousands dead and many more left homeless in Turkey and Syria, people struggling to unearth victims, bury the dead and provide for millions of survivors are pleading for more aid.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard, Safak Timur, Vivian Yee and Gulsin Harman
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rescue workers digging in the rubble of a collapsed house on Wednesday in Iskenderun, Turkey.

item.title: Visiting U.K. and France, Zelensky Pleads for Jets and Weapons for Ukraine
item.description: In a surprise visit that started a two-day blitz of Western allies, the Ukrainian president implored Britain to provide planes he said would represent “wings of freedom.’’
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine and Prime Minister Rishi Sunak of Britain visiting a military facility to meet Ukrainian soldiers being trained to use Challenger 2 tanks on Wednesday in Dorset, England.

item.title: Christian Atsu Still Missing After Turkey Earthquake Despite Reports, Club Says
item.description: It was unclear whether Mr. Atsu, a Ghanaian national, was still trapped underneath the rubble in Hatay Province, Turkey, or whether he had been removed but could not be located in the region’s overwhelmed hospitals.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil
item.media:description: Christian Atsu in Newcastle, England, in 2020.

item.title: Why the Odds Are Stacked Against a Promising New Covid Drug
item.description: A new drug quashes all coronavirus variants. But regulatory hurdles and a lack of funding make it unlikely to reach the U.S. market anytime soon.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mueller
item.media:description: A Covid patient was ushered into an ambulance in Brazil, one of two countries that held clinical trials of 2,000 patients for the pegylated interferon lambda injection.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: Frustration Mounts in Turkey
item.description: Also, Volodymyr Zelensky visits Britain and LeBron James breaks a record.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg and Mariah Kreutter
item.media:credit: Photo by Adem Altan/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan tours the site of destroyed buildings during his visit to the city of Kahramanmaras in southeast Turkey on Wednesday.

item.title: Putin Likely Approved Missile System Used to Down Flight MH17, Inquiry Says
item.description: A Dutch-led team made the assessment, but said it had suspended its investigation because of insufficient evidence and rules that prevent new prosecutions.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Local workers transport a piece of wreckage from Malaysia Airlines flight MH17 at the site of the plane crash in eastern Ukraine in 2014.

item.title: Twitter Was Blocked in Turkey After Earthquake, Internet-Monitoring Group Says
item.description: The service was blocked in what appeared to be a coordinated way.
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano

item.title: State of Uncertainty
item.description: What Biden said, and didn’t, in his State of the Union speech.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:description: President Joe Biden delivering his State of the Union address.

item.title: China’s Bid to Improve Food Production? Giant Towers of Pigs.
item.description: High-rise hog farms have sprung up nationwide as part of Beijing’s drive to enhance its agricultural competitiveness and reduce its dependence on imports.
item.dc:creator: Daisuke Wakabayashi and Claire Fu

item.title: Zelensky thanks Britain during his second overseas trip since Russia’s invasion.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine in Kyiv, the country’s capital, last week.

item.title: Grieving Turkish Diaspora Rallies to Support Turkey Earthquake Victims
item.description: In Melbourne, Australia, dozens of volunteers in the parking lot behind a halal butcher shop packed three shipping containers with cardboard boxes full of new tents, blankets and sleeping bags.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Members of the Turkish Australian community in Melbourne, Australia, packing tents, blankets and sleeping bags to be shipped to earthquake victims in Turkey.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: The rising death toll in Turkey and Syria from the earthquake.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Emin Ozmen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rescue workers at a collapsed building in Malatya, Turkey, on Tuesday.

item.title: Biden Focuses on Domestic Issues in State of the Union Despite Global Tensions
item.description: Mr. Biden is proud of reshaping foreign policy to focus on superpower conflict, but knows it is jobs and energy prices that voters want to hear about.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:description: Oksana Markarova, the Ukrainian ambassador, was a guest at the State of the Union address, as she was last year, but President Biden mentioned Ukraine only briefly this time.

item.title: After Spy Balloon Clash, U.S.-China Tensions Loom Over Biden’s Speech
item.description: The president has taken steps meant to limit China’s technological advancement and bolster military forces in the Asia-Pacific region.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: President Biden has taken economic and military steps aimed at limiting China.

item.title: Videos Show Desperate Search for Survivors Near Quake’s Epicenter in Turkey
item.description: Hatay Province had Turkey’s highest-known death toll from Monday’s earthquake.
item.dc:creator: Tolga Ildun, Sarah Kerr, Axel Boada and Vivian Yee

item.title: After Spy Balloon Incident, China Rejects Pentagon’s Request to Speak
item.description: Chinese officials rejected a request from the U.S. defense secretary to speak with his counterpart after an American fighter jet shot down a Chinese spy balloon.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Chad Fish/Chad Fish, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The balloon after it was downed on Saturday. Navy divers are trying to recover its sensors and other surveillance equipment.

item.title: Felipe Calderón, Former Mexican President, Accused of Supporting Sinaloa Cartel
item.description: The accusation, which was quickly denied, was made by a former Mexican official at the trial in Brooklyn of Mexico’s former top security chief.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer and Maria Abi-Habib
item.media:credit: Susana Gonzalez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Felipe Calderón during an interview with The New York Times at his office in 2011, when he was the president of Mexico.

item.title: Russia Pays a Bloody Price for Small Gains in Eastern Ukraine
item.description: Russia is relying on masses of troops to overrun Ukrainian positions, producing heavy casualties and incremental gains.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora, Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Shashank Bengali
item.media:description: A billboard with an image of a Russian service member and a slogan reading “Glory to the Heroes of Russia!” in St. Petersburg, Russia, on Monday.

item.title: Baby Born in Rubble of Turkey-Syria Earthquake is One of Many Child Victims
item.description: Harrowing images have emerged of some of the millions of children caught in the catastrophic earthquake in Turkey and Syria.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi and Hwaida Saad
item.media:description: A baby girl who was born under the rubble caused by an earthquake received treatment at a children’s hospital in the town of Afrin, Aleppo province, Syria, on Tuesday.

item.title: Mukarram Jah, Heir to an Opulent Throne He Abandoned, Dies at 89
item.description: He descended from famed Islamic royalty in India and Turkey, but later fled to Australia and became a sheep farmer.
item.dc:creator: Alex Traub
item.media:description: Mr. Jah with Princess Esra, center, at Chowmahalla Palace in Hyderabad in 1967, the year he was crowned nizam.

item.title: Turkey and Syria Earthquake Death Toll Tops 7,700 As Rescuers Fight Weather
item.description: Shoveling snow and rubble, emergency crews worked across hundreds of miles in Turkey and Syria to save people in the aftermath of the most powerful quake in the region in decades.
item.dc:creator: Safak Timur, Ben Hubbard and Gulsin Harman
item.media:credit: Emin Ozmen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rescue workers carrying Salih Polat, 27, from a collapsed building in Malatya, on Tuesday.

item.title: Joy and Heartache Follow Earthquake Rescue in Turkish City of Gaziantep
item.description: In the hard-hit Turkish city of Gaziantep, a collapsed apartment building spared few of its residents. But one man heard his brother’s voice from beneath the debris.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Safak Timur

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing: Quake’s Death Toll Soars
item.description: Also, China’s balloon spin and Russia’s mounting losses.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg and Mariah Kreutter
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Emin Ozmen for The New York Times
item.media:description: After an intensive search, rescue workers saved Vacit Amuri, a 3-year-old girl from a Syrian family, from a collapsed building on Tuesday.

item.title: At Cooper Union, a Russian Design Show Caught in a Political Crossfire
item.description: After indefinitely postponing a modest student exhibit about the Russian equivalent to the Bauhaus, the school received protests from 750 academics. On Monday, it reinstated the show.
item.dc:creator: Joseph Giovannini
item.category: Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art
item.media:credit: George Etheredge for The New York Times
item.media:description: Anna Bokov, an assistant adjunct professor, outside Cooper Union, in a neighborhood known as Little Ukraine. Her exhibition about a century-old Moscow design school was postponed when an article raised questions about its timing. On Monday, the school reinstated the show.

item.title: As Sunak Tries to Move Ahead, He’s Haunted by Prime Ministers Past
item.description: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak of Britain made moves to recharge his government, but he is being harried by Liz Truss and Boris Johnson, who are not fading away.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak of Britain shuffled his cabinet on Tuesday.

item.title: 3 E.U. Countries Plan to Get Some Leopard 1 Tanks to Ukraine ‘Within Months’
item.description: The new initiative aims to boost Kyiv’s supply of tanks faster as more advanced tanks will take many months to arrive.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.media:description: Leopard 1 A5 tanks in a production facility in Germany.

item.title: Erdogan’s Response to Turkey’s Earthquake Could Determine His Re-Election
item.description: The Turkish president swept to power two decades ago after the government botched its response to a 1999 earthquake. Monday’s quake adds to his challenges an election just a few months away.
item.dc:creator: Gulsin Harman and Matt Surman
item.media:description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey in Ankara in January.

item.title: Pentagon Lifts Trump-Era Ban on Release of Guantánamo Prisoners’ Art
item.description: The Trump administration called detainee art U.S. government property and halted most releases. Lawyers never mounted an intellectual property case.
item.dc:creator: Carol Rosenberg
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: The prisoner Mohammed Ahmed Ghulam Rabbani painted this scene at Guantánamo Bay and gave it to a lawyer before the Trump administration banned all such releases in 2017. Mr. Rabbani, who is one of 20 prisoners eligible for transfer, wants to take with him all the paintings he has at the prison when he is repatriated to Pakistan.

item.title: The Sole Border Crossing for U.N. Aid From Turkey to Syria Is Blocked
item.description: As the Syrian government tightly controls what aid it allows into opposition-held areas, border crossings with Turkey have been a lifeline.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost and Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:description: Mourning victims of the earthquake in Jandaris, a town in the opposition-held part of Aleppo Province, in Syria on Tuesday.

item.title: David Carrick Is Sentenced to Life for Rape and Sexual Abuse
item.description: David Carrick had pleaded guilty to 49 crimes against 12 women in the latest case to cast a harsh spotlight on the Metropolitan Police.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Wiktor Szymanowicz/Anadolu Agency, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Activists gathering for a protest outside Southwark Crown Court in London on Monday during the sentencing trial of David Carrick, a former police officer.

item.title: Searching for Survivors
item.description: Time is running out, and cold weather is impeding the search for survivors after a major earthquake hit Turkey.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt and Claire Moses
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Searching for survivors in Adana, Turkey, this morning.

item.title: China Tries to Play Down Balloon Dispute With Censorship and Memes
item.description: Chinese propaganda also appears to be walking a fine line: looking tough for the crowd at home, without further derailing relations with the United States.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang and Joy Dong
item.media:description: Outside the Foreign Ministry in Beijing on Monday.

item.title: In a First, South Korea Is Ordered to Compensate a Vietnam War Victim
item.description: A court ruling held that South Korean troops were responsible for a civilian massacre that killed more than 70 villagers in Vietnam during the war.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Linh Pham for The New York Times
item.media:description: A memorial site marks the area in Vietnam where South Korean marines were accused of killing more than 70 unarmed Vietnamese civilians in 1968.

item.title: This Cystic Fibrosis Drug Is a ‘Miracle’ but These Families Can’t Get It
item.description: Vertex Pharmaceuticals is not making its drug, Trikafta, available in poorer countries, where thousands of diagnosed patients stand to benefit.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Nolen and Rebecca Robbins
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Shwetha Sree, left, with her 5-year-old son Vihaan, who has cystic fibrosis. He would be eligible for Vertex’s drug on his 6th birthday were he to live in the U.S.
